questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with difficulty chewing and numbness on the right side of his jaw following a recent sports injury. Examination reveals weakened jaw clenching on the right and decreased sensation over the anterior cheek, but intact sensation in the lower lip. Which of the following nerves might be affected?
questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior division of mandibular nerve

questions.text: Match each type of haemorrhage with its corresponding source of bleeding and Location. Which of the following combinations is correct? Type of Hemorrhage Source of Bleeding Location a. Epidural Hemorrhage 1. Middle meningeal artery i. b. Subdural Hemorrhage 2. Bridging veins ii. c. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage 3. Cerebral arteries iii. d. Intracerebral Hemorrhage 4. Ruptured cerebral aneurysm iv.
questions.explanation:
Type of Hemorrhage

Source of Bleeding

Location of Blood Collection

Symptoms

Epidural Hemorrhage

Middle meningeal artery

Between the skull bone and endosteal layer of the dura mater.



 
  • Acute symptoms, late paralysis starting with the face and spreading to the lower body
  • A lucid interval refers to a temporary period of clarity and responsiveness after a head injury, is seen in epidural hematoma, followed by a rapid neurological decline as the hematoma expands

Subdural Hemorrhage

Bridging veins (venous bleed)

Between dura mater and arachnoid mater.

Slower progression of cerebral compression, haphazard progression of paralysis.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

Rupture of small arteries (e.g., aneurysms)

Subarachnoid space at the base of the brain (cisterns)

Severe headache ("thunderclap headache"), often caused by aneurysm rupture or hypertension

Intracerebral Hemorrhage

Rupture of arteries within brain parenchyma

Brain tissue (parenchyma) itself, often in basal ganglia or cortex


 

Sudden onset of focal neurological deficits, headache, vomiting, altered consciousness.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with severe head trauma. His GCS is 5. On examination, there is a loss of sensation below the level of the neck and flaccid paralysis of all four limbs. Which of the following structures pass through the same cranial foramen as the structure involved in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Spinal root of accessory nerve

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly distinguishes the role of the hypoglossal nerve from the olfactory nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the muscles of the tongue, while the olfactory nerve mediates smell via the thalamus.

options.label: B
options.text: The hypoglossal nerve is involved in motor control of the tongue, while the olfactory nerve mediates smell without synapsing in the thalamus.

options.label: C
options.text: The hypoglossal nerve supplies the tongue and is part of the olfactory pathway.

options.label: D
options.text: Both the hypoglossal and olfactory nerves are involved in taste and smell.

questions.correct_answer: B. The hypoglossal nerve is involved in motor control of the tongue, while the olfactory nerve mediates smell without synapsing in the thalamus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with difficulty swallowing and a hoarse voice after recent neck surgery. What structure does the vagus nerve primarily run between as it descends in the neck?

options.label: A
options.text: Internal carotid artery and external jugular vein

options.label: B
options.text: Internal jugular vein and common carotid artery

options.label: C
options.text: Subclavian artery and internal thoracic artery

options.label: D
options.text: External carotid artery and internal jugular vein

questions.correct_answer: B. Internal jugular vein and common carotid artery

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Physical examination reveals a diminished gag reflex and weakened pharyngeal elevation during swallowing. Which of the following structures is not innervated by the affected nerve?
questions.explanation:
Fibers

Function

Nucleus

Special Visceral Efferent

Supplies Stylopharyngeus muscle

Nucleus Ambiguous

General Visceral Efferent

Secretomotor innervation to the Parotid gland

Inferior Salivatory Nucleus.

Special Visceral Afferent

Taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue (including vallate papillae)

Nucleus Tractus Solitarius.

General Visceral Afferent

Carry pain, touch, and temperature sensations from the pharynx, tonsils, soft palate, and posterior one-third of the tongue

Dorsal Nucleus of the Vagus.

General Somatic Afferent

Carry proprioceptive sensations from the stylopharyngeus muscle and skin of the auricle.

Spinal Nucleus of the Trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: Patient presented with a painful swelling as shown below. Senior doctor says the pain is due to the underlying fascia. All of the following structures are enclosed by the layer forming this fascia except
questions.explanation:
Location
  • Lies deep to the platysma, encircling the neck like a collar
  • Forms the roof of the posterior triangle of the neck

Superior Attachments
  • External occipital protuberance
  • Superior nuchal line
  • Mastoid process, styloid process
  • External acoustic meatus
  • Base of the mandible

Inferior Attachments

Spine of scapula

Posterior Attachments
  • Ligamentum nuchae
  • Spine of seventh cervical vertebra (C7)

Anterior Attachments
  • Symphysis menti
  • Hyoid bone

Enclosed Structures
  • Muscles: Trapezius (Option B), Sternocleidomastoid
  • Salivary glands: Parotid, Submandibular gland (Option C)

  • Spaces:
    • Suprasternal space of Burns: Sternal heads of bilateral sternocleidomastoid; Jugular venous arch; Interclavicular ligament
    • Supraclavicular space: External jugular vein (Option D) ; Supraclavicular nerves
  • Forms pulleys for digastric and omohyoid tendons
  • Forms roof of anterior and posterior triangles
  • Forms stylomandibular ligament (separates parotid gland from the submandibular gland) and parotido-masseteric fascia

questions.text: You notice the following examination being done in ED, all of the following are boundaries of the space containing the palpated structure except
questions.explanation:
Boundaries
  • Anterosuperior: Posterior belly of digastric (vs Option A); Stylohyoid (Option B)
  • Anteroinferior: Superior belly of omohyoid (Option C)
  • Posterior: Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid (Option D)

Floor:
  • Thyrohyoid
  • Hyoglossus
  • Middle constrictor
  • Inferior constrictor

Contents
  • Carotid arteries: Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery, External carotid artery and its first five branches (superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal and occipital)
  • Carotid sinus and carotid body
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Last three cranial nerves: Vagus nerve, Spinal accessory nerve, Hypoglossal nerve
  • Carotid sheath
  • Ansa cervicalis
  • Cervical part of the sympathetic chain
  • Deep cervical lymph nodes

questions.text: Choose the appropriate set of correct statement(s) regarding the triangle shown in the image below (red-shaded region) 1) bounded posteroinferiorly by posterior belly of digastric 2) Floor of the triangle is formed by hyoglossus anteriorly 3) Submental artery runs through anterior part of triangle 4) Carotid artery runs through posterior part of triangle
questions.explanation:
Description:
  • Also known as submandibular triangle
  • Enclosed between two bellies of digastric muscle

Attachments:

Anteroinferiorly

Anterior belly of the digastric muscle

Posteroinferiorly

Posterior belly of the digastric muscle (Statement 1) and stylohyoid muscle

Base

Base of the mandible, with an imaginary line from the mandible angle to the mastoid process

Apex

Intermediate tendon of the digastric muscle

Floor:

Anteriorly

Mylohyoid (Statement 2)

Posteriorly

Hyoglossus

Roof:
  • Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: Encloses submandibular lymph nodes
  • Superficial fascia: Platysma, cervical branch of facial nerve, ascending branch of transverse cervical nerve

Contents:

Anterior part
  • Submandibular salivary gland
  • Submandibular lymph nodes
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Facial vein (superficial to gland)
  • Facial artery (deep to gland)
  • Submental artery (Statement 3)
  • Mylohyoid nerve and vessels


 

Posterior part
  • External carotid artery (Statement 4)
  • Carotid sheath and contents: Internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, vagus nerve
  • Structures passing between the external and internal carotid arteries: Styloglossus, stylopharyngeus, glossopharyngeal nerve, styloid process

questions.text: A patient presents with the following symptoms: when sticking out the tongue, it deviates towards the left side, and there is noticeable atrophy on the left side of the tongue. Based on the image, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
During a thyroidectomy, the surgeon identifies an artery supplying the lower part of the thyroid isthmus, originating from the arch of the aorta. What is the name of this artery?

A 12 y/o boy presents with nasal bleeding, after nose-picking. On examination, the bleeding site is located in the anterior nasal septum, and the diagnosis of epistaxis from Kiesselbach's plexus is made. Which of the following arteries is LEAST likely to contribute to the bleeding from this plexus?
questions.explanation:
Artery

Branch of

Region Supplied

Anterior ethmoid artery

(Option A)

Ophthalmic artery

Anterosuperior portion of the nasal septum

Sphenopalatine artery

(Option D)

Maxillary artery

Posteroinferior portion of the nasal septum

Septal branch of superior labial artery

(Option C)

Facial artery

Caudal septum and columella

Greater palatine artery

Maxillary artery

Anteroinferior portion of the nasal septum

questions.text: Which of the following is not the branch of the marked artery?
Which of the following statements about the scalenus anterior muscle is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The phrenic nerve lies anteriorly to the muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: The thoracic duct arches laterally on the right side.

options.label: C
options.text: The brachial plexus is posterior to the muscle.

options.label: D
options.text: The lateral part of the carotid sheath contains the internal jugular vein.

questions.correct_answer: B. The thoracic duct arches laterally on the right side.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of hydrocephalus and developmental delays. An MRI reveals a malformation of a vein associated with increased intracranial pressure. Which of the following veins primarily contributes to its formation?

A 40-year-old female presents with double vision and drooping eyelids. An MRI reveals involvement of the cavernous sinus, prompting the neurologist to evaluate the cranial nerves associated with this structure. Which of the following nerves is not a content of the cavernous sinus?
questions.explanation:
Superior

Optic chiasma, optic tract, internal carotid artery, anterior perforated substance.

Inferior

Foramen lacerum, junction of the body and greater wing of the sphenoid.

Medial

Pituitary gland (hypophysis cerebri), sphenoid air sinus.

Lateral

Temporal lobe (uncus), cavum trigeminale containing the trigeminal ganglion.

Anterior

Superior orbital fissure, apex of the orbit.

Posterior

Crus cerebri of the midbrain, apex of the petrous temporal bone.

Structures present in the Lateral Wall

Structures passing through the sinus

Superior to Inferior:

  • Oculomotor nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Ophthalmic nerve
  • Maxillary nerve
  • Internal Carotid Artery: Surrounded by a sympathetic nerve plexus.
  • Abducent Nerve runs alongside the artery. It is first involved in cavernous sinus thrombosis. Thus abduction defect is the earliest clinical sign observed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes surgery for a suspected brain mass. During the operation, the surgeon identifies a dural fold extending between the cerebellum and the occipital lobes, creating a partition in the cranial cavity. Which dural fold is being described?

A 35-year-old female presents with sharp, shooting pain and numbness in her forehead, upper eyelid, upper face, upper lip, and part of her cheek after a recent car accident. She has a diminished corneal reflex on the right side. Which divisions of the trigeminal nerve are affected?
questions.explanation:
Ophthalmic division (V1)

Maxillary division (V2)

Mandibular division (V3)

Type

Sensory

Sensory

Mixed

Course

Branches

Frontal

  • Supratrochlear
  • Supraorbital

Nasociliary

  • Branch to the ciliary ganglion
  • 2–3 long ciliary nerves
  • Posterior ethmoidal
  • Infratrochlear
  • Anterior ethmoidal

Lacrimal: Branch to the upper eyelid and secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal gland.
  • Infraorbital
  • Zygomaticofacial
  • Zygomaticotemporal
  • Mental
  • Buccal
  • Auriculo-temporal

Supply

  • Forehead
  • Upper eyelids
  • Root of nose
  • Tip of nose
  • Frontal air sinus
  • Scalp
  • Lower eyelids
  • Lateral sides of the nose
  • Upper lip
  • Cheek (upper part)
  • Anterior part of the temporal region
  • Lower lip
  • Chin
  • Lower teeth
  • Lower part of the cheek
  • Lateral side (Upper 2/3rd) of auricle, temporal region

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the structures within the parotid gland are accurate? The external carotid artery enters the parotid gland through the posteromedial surface. The maxillary artery exits through the posterior surface of the gland. The superficial temporal artery branches into the transverse facial artery and emerges from the anterior part of the superior surface. The superficial temporal vein and maxillary vein unite to form the retromandibular vein, which divides into anterior and posterior divisions near the apex of the gland. The facial nerve enters the parotid gland and passes behind the retromandibular vein.
questions.explanation:
Structures Within the Parotid Gland

Arteries

 
  • External Carotid Artery: Enters through the posteromedial surface.
  • Maxillary Artery: Exits through the anteromedial surface.
  • Superficial Temporal Artery: Branches into the transverse facial artery and emerges from the anterior part of the superior surface.

Veins

 
  • Superficial Temporal Vein and Maxillary Vein unite to form the Retromandibular Vein, which divides into anterior and posterior divisions near the apex of the gland.

Facial Nerve
  • Exits the skull through the Stylomastoid Foramen, enters the parotid gland at the posteromedial surface, passing in front of the retromandibular vein and external carotid artery.
  • Divides into Temporofacial and Cervicofacial branches near the neck of the mandible, further branching into five terminal branches: Temporal, Zygomatic, Buccal, Marginal Mandibular, and Cervical, exiting along the anterior border and apex of the gland.

Lymphatics
  • Contains parotid lymph nodes located in the superficial fascia and deep to the deep fascia over the gland.

Parotid Duct/ Stensen's Duct
  • About 5 cm long.
  • Origin: Emerges from the middle of the parotid gland's anterior border.
  • Course: Runs forward over the masseter muscle, then makes a medial turn at the masseter's anterior border.
  • Structures Pierced:
    • Buccal Pad of Fat
    • Buccopharyngeal Fascia
    • Buccinator Muscle (penetrates obliquely)
  • Termination: After passing through the buccinator, the duct travels briefly between the buccinator and oral mucosa, then opens into the vestibule of the mouth opposite the upper second molar's crown.
  • This oblique passage prevents the duct from inflating with air when blowing.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to the formation of the marked structure?
questions.correct_answer: D. Greater wing of the sphenoid

questions.text: A 34 y/o male presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He complains of difficulty in chewing and numbness over the lower jaw. Upon examination, he has weakness in the muscles of mastication. Which of the following structures do not course along with the nerve implicated in the patient's symptoms through the same cranial foramen?
What is the structure marked as X in the laryngoscopy diagram given below?

Match the spaces between the constrictor muscles with the structures that pass through them: Spaces Structures 1) Sinus of Morgagni A) Internal laryngeal nerve, superior laryngeal vessels 2) Space between superior and middle constrictors B) Recurrent laryngeal nerve, inferior laryngeal vessels 3) Space between middle and inferior constrictors C) Stylopharyngeus muscle, glossopharyngeal nerve 4) Space below the inferior constrictor D) Auditory tube, levator veli palatini muscle, ascending palatine artery, palatine branch of ascending pharyngeal artery
questions.explanation:
Constrictors muscles and the spaces between them

Constrictor Muscles of the Pharynx

Form the outer circular layer and overlap each other.

  • Superior Constrictor:
    • Originates from the pterygoid hamulus, pterygomandibular raphe, mandible, and the side of the posterior tongue.
    • Its upper border is attached to the base of the skull, leaving a space called the sinus of Morgagni, filled by the pharyngobasilar fascia.
  • Middle Constrictor:
    • Overlaps the lower part of the superior constrictor.
    • Originates from the stylohyoid ligament, lesser cornua, and the upper border of the greater cornua of the hyoid bone.
    • The stylopharyngeus muscle and glossopharyngeal nerve pass through the gap between the superior and middle constrictors.
  • Inferior Constrictor:
    • Overlapping the middle constrictor.
    • Composed of two parts:
      • Thyropharyngeus: Originates from the oblique line of the thyroid cartilage.
      • Cricopharyngeus: Originates from the cricoid cartilage.
    • The internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels pass through the gap between the middle and inferior constrictors.

All three constrictor muscles attach to the median raphe at the posterior pharyngeal wall. The top of this raphe connects to the pharyngeal tubercle at the skull base, while the lower edge of the inferior constrictor blends with the esophagus' circular muscle.

Spaces Between the Constrictor Muscles

(Option A)

The overlapping nature of these muscles forms spaces through which nerves and blood vessels pass:

 


  • Sinus of Morgagni (between the superior constrictor's upper border and the skull base):
    • Allows the passage of the auditory tube, levator veli palatini muscle, ascending palatine artery, and the palatine branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery.
  • Space between the superior and middle constrictors:
    • Contains the stylopharyngeus muscle and glossopharyngeal nerve.
  • Space between the middle and inferior constrictors:
    • Contains the internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels.
  • Space below the inferior constrictor:
    • Contains the recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels.

Killian's Dehiscence
  • Location: At the lower part of the posterior pharyngeal wall, below the vocal folds and above the cricopharyngeal sphincter.
  • Clinically significant area as it is a weak point. (Thyropharyngeus muscle is not reinforced internally by other constrictors)
  • The area is often associated with the formation of pharyngeal diverticula.

questions.text: Match the walls of the orbit with the bones forming it Wall Bone a. Roof 1. Greater wing of sphenoid b. Lateral wall 2. Orbital surface of maxilla c. Floor 3. Orbital plate of frontal d. Medial wall 4. Lacrimal
questions.explanation:
Orbital Wall

Structures Forming the Wall

Roof
  • Orbital plate of the frontal bone (main part)
  • Lesser wing of the sphenoid (posterior part)

Lateral Wall
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone (posterior part)
  • Orbital surface of the frontal process of the zygomatic bone (anterior part)

Floor
  • Orbital surface of the maxilla (main part)
  • Lower part of the orbital surface of the zygomatic bone (anterolaterally)
  • Orbital process of the palatine bone (posterior angle)

Medial Wall

From before backward:

  • Frontal process of the maxilla
  • Lacrimal bone
  • Orbital plate of the ethmoid bone
  • Body of the sphenoid bone

questions.text: Which of the following is not a structure passing through the superior orbital fissure?
questions.explanation:
Part

Structures Passing Through

Lateral Part
  • Lacrimal nerve (branch of ophthalmic nerve)
  • Frontal nerve (branch of ophthalmic nerve)
  • Trochlear nerve (CN IV)
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Meningeal branch of lacrimal artery
  •  Anastomotic branch of middle meningeal artery (anastomoses with recurrent branch of lacrimal artery)

Middle Part
  • Upper division of oculomotor nerve (CN III)
  • Lower division of oculomotor nerve (CN III)
  • Nasociliary nerve
  • Abducens nerve (CN VI)

Medial Part
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
  • Sympathetic nerve from plexus around internal carotid artery

questions.text: A young female with history of recurrent attacks of pain over medial canthus of eye and cheek presents with chills, rigor, diplopia on lateral gaze and restriction of eye movements. She was diagnosed with PCOS and is on OCPs for the same since 6 months. On examination, edema over eyelids and exophthalmos were noted. Choose the correct combination regarding communication of the most likely structure affected in this patient.

options.label: A
options.text: Transverse sinus through Inferior petrosal sinus

options.label: B
options.text: Internal jugular vein through emissary veins

options.label: C
options.text: Pterygoid plexus through superior petrosal sinus

options.label: D
options.text: Facial vein through superior ophthalmic vein

questions.correct_answer: D. Facial vein through superior ophthalmic vein
questions.explanation:
Tributaries:

From the Orbit
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
  • Central vein of the retina (drains into either the superior ophthalmic vein or directly into the cavernous sinus)

From the Brain
  • Superficial middle cerebral vein
  • Inferior cerebral veins

From the Meninges
  • Sphenoparietal sinus
  • Frontal trunk of the middle meningeal vein

Communications

Vein/sinus

Via

Transverse sinus

Superior petrosal sinus (Option A)

Internal jugular vein

Inferior petrosal sinus (Option B)

Pterygoid plexus

Emissary veins (Option C)

Facial vein

Superior ophthalmic vein (Option D)

Right and Left cavernous sinuses

Anterior and posterior intercavernous sinuses

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident presented to the ED in a confused state. Ecchymosis around the eyes was noted, and CT showed the following. Which of the following does not contribute to the floor of the affected structure?

options.label: C
options.text: Orbital plate of the frontal bone

questions.explanation:
Floor
  • Cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone (anterior) (Option A)
  • Superior surface of the anterior part of the body of the sphenoid or Jugum sphenoidale (posterior)
  • Lesser wing of sphenoid (posterior) (Option B)
  • Orbital plate of frontal (on either side) (Option C)

questions.text: Which among the following are pneumatic bones?
The base of the skull is primarily formed by which type of ossification?
questions.explanation:
Membranous Ossification

Endochondral Ossification
  • Bone forms directly from mesenchymal tissue without a cartilage intermediate.
  • Cranial vault forms through membranous ossification
 

Bones that undergo membranous ossification:

  • Flat bones of the skull which include bones like the
    • frontal bone
    • parietal bones
    • nasal bones
    • lacrimal bones
    • squamous part of the temporal and occipital bones
 
  • Maxilla and Mandible (except the condylar process of the mandible, which forms by endochondral ossification).
 
  • Process: Mesenchymal cells differentiate into osteoblasts, which start forming bone directly by secreting osteoid (bone matrix). This process is characteristic of the bones that contribute to the vault of the skull (calvaria).
  • Bone is formed by first creating a cartilage template, which is then replaced by bone.
  • Cranial base forms though endochondral ossification
 

Bones that undergo endochondral ossification:

  • Base of the skull:
    • Occipital bone (except the squamous part)
    • Sphenoid bone
    • Ethmoid bone
    • Petrous part of the temporal bone
 
  • Condyle of the mandible.
 
  • Process: In endochondral ossification, a cartilage model of the bone forms first. This cartilage is progressively replaced by bone as it is calcified and invaded by blood vessels, bringing osteoblasts and osteoclasts to reshape the bone.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves provides general sensation to the area of the tongue marked in blue?
questions.explanation:
Part of Tongue

General Sensation

Taste Sensation

Anterior two-third
  • Trigeminal nerve (V3) (specifically the lingual branch)
  • Chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (CN VII)

Posterior one-third
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Root of the tongue and the area around the epiglottis
  • Vagus nerve (CN X)
  • Vagus nerve (CN X)

questions.text: Below is an image of a transverse section of the lower pons, specifically at the level of the facial colliculus. Please identify the structures marked as "X" and "Y."
questions.correct_answer: A. Abducens nucleus and Facial nucleus

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with diabetes arrives at the emergency department with sudden right-sided weakness and trouble speaking. His examination shows left-sided ptosis, the left eye in a "down and out" position, and right-sided paralysis of the lower face. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old patient presents with difficulty in smiling and closing eyelids on the right side. The patient does not have any history of recent trauma or infections. The image below shows the patient's face. Sensory function, including taste on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and sensation to light touch, appears intact. Which nerve column is primarily responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Nerve Column

Nucleus Origin

Function

Special Visceral Afferent

Nucleus Solitarius

Carries taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue via the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

General Visceral Efferent

Superior salivatory nucleus

Parasympathetic innervation to glands (lacrimal, submandibular, sublingual).

Special Visceral Efferent

Facial nucleus in the pons

Innervates muscles derived from branchial (pharyngeal) arches.

General Somatic Afferent

Geniculate ganglion

Carries sensory information from the skin (e.g., touch, pain).
